titlestmt.titleproper:
Guide to the Between C & D Archive
circa 1983-1990
MSS 084
titlestmt.author: Finding aid prepared by Marvin J. Taylor/ Tania Friedel, July-August 1997.

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using the Archivists' Toolkit 2014-12-05T12:13-0500

did.abstract: Between C & D was one of the most influential literary magazines of the New York downtown scene in the 1980s, founded by Joel Rose and Catherine Texier in 1983. Taking its name from the location of Rose and Texier's apartment where it was produced--on East 7th Street between Avenues C & D on Manhattan's Lower East Side--the magazine provided one of the major downtown venues for "new fiction" of both established and emerging writers like Patrick McGrath, Dennis Cooper, Gary Indiana, Kathy Acker, Lynne Tillman, and David Wojnarowicz, to name only a few. Rose and Texier's vision for Between C & D was to support writing that deviated from conventional norms and questioned accepted standards of literature. The magazine stopped publication in 1990. The collection contains the editorial correspondence, manuscripts, and copies of Between C & D, and various related materials.

custodhist.head: Provenance
custodhist.p: Purchased from Joel Rose and Catherine Texier in July of 1996, the printed materials were removed and cataloged in the Downtown Collection and are listed in BobCat (a special subject heading "Downtown Writers" was given to all materials in the collection as a means of retrieving all works about downtown New York). Archival materials were sorted into series and processed later. As much as possible, the editors' original organization of the material was preserved.

accessrestrict.head: Access Restrictions
accessrestrict.p: Open to researchers. Appointments are necessary for the use of manuscript and archival materials.

bioghist.head: Historical Note
bioghist.p: Between C & D was started in 1983 by co-editors Joel Rose and Catherine Texier. Taking its name from the location of Rose and Texier's apartment where it was produced--on East Seventh Street between Avenues C and D on Manhattan's Lower East Side--the magazine provided one of the major downtown venues for new fiction of both established and emerging writers like Patrick McGrath, Dennis Cooper, Gary Indiana, Kathy Acker, Lynne Tillman, and David Wojnarowicz, to name only a few. Rose and Texier are themselves important writers of the downtown scene. Rose has written two novels: Kill the Poor and Kill Kill Faster Faster; Texier is the author of novels Chloe l'Atlantique, written in her native French, and Love Me Tender, in English. As the cover of Between C & D illustrates, sex, drugs, violence, danger and computers were recurring motifs throughout the life of the magazine. Rose and Texier utilized the computer technology available to them in the production of the magazine. Not only were the layouts done on an Epson computer, but each issue was individually printed in their apartment on dot-matrix printers. Each issue was then individually packed into a Ziploc bag reminiscent of those used to sell drugs in the neighborhood. Rose and Texier's vision for Between C & D was to support writing that deviated from conventional norms and questioned accepted standards of literature. Thus, much of the writing featured in Between C & D focuses on the gritty underside of urban living; often shock value is employed, and the safety of middle-class standards are attacked for their underlying hypocrisy. In 1988, Penguin published an anthology of Between C & D for its Contemporary American Fiction series that included twenty-five writers chosen by Rose and Texier to represent the magazine's scope and content. The magazine stopped publication in 1990.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: The Between C & D Archive was acquired via purchase from Joel Rose and Catherine Texier in July of 1996. The collection included a complete set of Joel's copy of the magazine with all variants, correspondence, manuscripts, posters, business files, ephemera, including the computer used for the production of the magazine, and miscellaneous printed materials. The collection was built by the editors of Between C & D, Joel Rose and Catherine Texier, themselves established writers and longtime members of the New York literary scene. The collection was sorted by Marvin J. Taylor once it arrived at NYU. Printed materials were removed and catalogued in the Downtown Collection and are listed in BobCat. A special subject heading "Downtown Writers" was given to all materials in the collection as a means of retrieving all works about downtown New York. Archival materials were sorted into series and processed later. Oversized archival materials from the various series are located in an oversize box at the end of the collection.

The Between C & D Archive comprises incoming and outgoing correspondence and business files for both the magazine and the anthology; production files for the magazine; a complete run of the magazine with all variants; manuscripts, posters, and original art; ephemera, including the computer used in the production of the magazine; disks containing the print files for the magazine, outgoing correspondence, and other related data for both the magazine and anthology; and miscellaneous printed materials. The scope of the archive is comprehensive in that it contains all records and files of the magazine and anthology kept by Joel Rose and Catherine Texier, editors of the magazine. As much as possible, the editors' original organization of the material was preserved.
Series I: Correspondence and Business Files

Series I contains three boxes of business and correspondence related materials, including administrative and financial records, manuscripts and cover art, arranged alphabetically in keeping with the original order of the files as received.
Series II: Production Files
Series II contains three boxes of production related materials for Between C & D.
Series III: Complete set of Between C & D
Series III contains two boxes of Joel's copy of the complete set of Between C & D with all variants.
Series IV: Anthology
Series IV contains one box of materials relating to the Between C & D anthology, including manuscripts, the galley, author biographies, permissions, publicity, correspondence and contracts.
Series V: Ephemera

Series V contains three boxes of Epson computer components, including the keyboard and monitor, and one box containing the floppy disks on which are located the print files for the magazine and anthology as well as back-up mailing lists, administrative forms, outgoing editorial correspondence and author biographies for the anthology, as well as two small gray boxes of stamp art used in the production of the magazine.
Series VI: Printed Material

Series VI contains one box of miscellaneous printed materials arranged alphabetically. Included are various little magazines contemporaneous with Between C & D and often containing fiction by authors that appear in Between C & D.
Oversize: A flat oversize box at the end of the collection contains oversize materials from Series I, II and IV.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Folders are arranged alphabetically by subject/author heading within the correspondence and manuscript series. In other series, folders are essentially alphabetically arranged with some anomalies to accommodate the various material types contained therein. The series containing issues of the magazine are arranged chronologically.
The files are grouped into six series and further subdivided into subseries for oversized materials.

list.item: Series I: Correspondence and Business Files
Series III: Joel's Copy with All Variants

relatedmaterial.head: Related Material at the Fales Library and Special Collections

separatedmaterial.head: Separated Material
separatedmaterial.p: Printed materials were removed and catalogued in the Downtown Collection. These items are listed in Bobcat. A local subject heading "Downtown Writers" was given to all materials in the collection as a means of retrieving all works about downtown New York

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: Collection use is subject to all copyright laws. Permission to publish materials must be obtained in writing from the Director of Fales Library and Special Collections. Please contact fales.library@nyu.edu. or call 212 998 2596.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p:
Published citations should take the following form:
Identification of item, date (if known); collection name; MSS number; box number; folder number; Fales Library and Special Collections, New York University Libraries.

did.physdesc: Illustration by Joel Rose (punk guy with mohawk and cross earring, black outline and pink fill)
Illustration by Joel Rose ("downtown" woman with high-heels, hoop earrings, and pony tail; black outline with yellow, red and blue fill)

Illustration by Joel Rose ("downtown" woman with voluminous side-hair, one hoop earring, significant cleavage and high-heels, black outline and yellow, red and pink fill)
Illustration by Rick Prol (Man with bound hands tied to a board, three daggers in mouth, anchor tattoo on shoulder. Black outline with green and brown fill).
Illustration by Rick Prol (floating head above dilapidated ship. black outline with green, brown, red, and blue fill).
Illustration by Rick Prol (canon and pirate with bandana and eye patch. black outline with black, brown and blue fill)

Illustration by Rick Prol (pirate with eyepatch wearing a bicorne hat, both legs replaced by one peg leg, planet earth in top-left. black outline with brown, grey, green, blue and pink fill)

Printed/Fabricated by Chris Costan (broken easter eggs on a textured blue background, from the right-hand egg a building emerges, and from the left-hand egg, a pot, plate, bowl and saucer are being lifted)

Printed/Fabricated by Chris Costan (three broken easter eggs, from which some carbon structures, a pineapple, and an elliptical map of the world are emerging. on top of a half-red and half-yellow background that features arabic writing.)
Printed/Fabricated by Chris Costan (two broken easter eggs, from which a triangle, a light bulb, a ruler and some clouds are emerging. on top of a textured pink background)
Printed/Fabricated by Chris Costan (two broken easter eggs, from whence a centipede and the constellation Perseus [holding the Pleiades] issue)
Salvadorian Cocktail Napkins (image - color: child with large hair - red, woman biting her finger - blue, child with flat hair - gold)

Cover text contains the date, volume, issue, contributer, and slogan information from the previous issue (v.2 #3) but the cover art is by Kiki Smith, and the following pages contain v.2 #4's masthead, table of contents, stories and inserted material.

Front cover by Kiki Smith (anatomical illustration of human organs, predominant color is dusky pink) Inserted material by Jolie Stahl (an illustration of a woman with a sheep, with green overlay and red text)

Front cover by Kiki Smith (anatomical illustration of human organs, predominant color is yellow ochre) Inserted material by Jolie Stahl (an illustration of a woman with a sheep, with brown overlay and red text)

Front cover by Kiki Smith (anatomical illustration of human organs, predominant color is pale blue-green) Inserted material by Jolie Stahl (an illustration of a woman with a sheep, with red overlay and red text)

Front cover by Kiki Smith (anatomical illustration of human organs, predominant color is blue/purple) Inserted material by Jolie Stahl (an illustration of a woman with a sheep, with red overlay and green text)
Mixed Media by Deborah Root Brague (illustrations of three women and one man on top of a forest scene; captions "I'LL KILL YOU, DARLING!" "NO, DON'T!" & "I'M GOING INSANE!")
Mixed Media by Deborah Rot Brague (illustrations of a head wearing a top hat and a large penis ontop of a photo of a woman in a bikini, on top of a photo of a garden; text box "THAT ISN'T MY BODY!")

Mixed Media by Deborah Root Brague (illustration of a man and a woman in Victorian garb, on top of an estate lawn, which is bisected, with a starscape behind; captions "IT'S HER FAULT!" and "IT'S HIS FAULT!")

Mixed Materials by Deborah Root Brague (illustration of two women in classic/al garb fighting and of a Greek statue, on top of a photo of a garden, with a starscape behind; caption "What a girl! She knew what she wanted - and she wasn't afraid to fight for it!")

Mixed Materials by Deborah Root Brague (illustrations of a victorian couple and a disembodied hand holding a handkerchief, on top of a photo of a red fainting couch, on top of a starscape; caption "YES, IT'S TRUE, DEAR, I HATE YOU!")
Print by Bonnie Lucas, from "Quality Time" (baby's bottle shooting milk and two rabbits in the foreground, a girl in a blue dress in the middleground, English garden in the background)

Print by Bonnie Lucas, from "Quality Time" (baby's bottle shooting milk and a girl's crotch in frilly shorts/underwear in the foreground, supine baby on a cushion in the middleground, floral "wallpaper" and yellow floor in the background)
Print by Bonnie Lucas, from "Quality Time" (baby's bottle shooting milk in the foreground, woman in a pink, ruffly dress in the middleground, flat blue background)

Imprint of a Painting by Orshi Drozdik (at the right foreground is a semi-dressed man embracing a resisting semi-dressed woman, who is reaching towards a chair; the background is predominantly a blue wallpaper [which contains some text] and a purple floor)

Imprint of a Painting by Orshi Drozdik (in the foreground, a man stradles a semi-prone woman, pulling her hair with one hand and the shoulder-strap of her dress with the other; the background is a predominantly pink wallpaper [which contains text] and a green floor)

Imprint of a Painting by Orshi Drozdik (in the left foreground, a man with an open shirt is forcing his way through the door of a resisting woman and grabbing her dress; the background is a predominantly green wallpaper [which contains text] and a checked pink-and-purple floor)
Sticker Sheet by Patrice Clare and Gregory Rukavina (three images of R. Budd Dwyer's suicide; loose sticker at top center)
Sticker Sheet by Patrice Claire and Gregory Rukavina (three images of R. Budd Dwyer's suicide; loose stickers in center column, top three rows)
Sticker Sheet by Patrice Claire and Gregory Rukavina (three images of R. Budd Dwyer's suicide; no loose stickers)
Illustration by Art Spiegelman (misspelled on the cover as "Art Spielgelman," but spelled correctly on masthead; images of many "average" people bound and blindfolded, standing against a brick wall)

Illustration by Art Spiegelman (misspelled on the cover as "Art Spielgelman," but spelled correctly on masthead; two punks having sex and lighting each other's cigarettes, in the left background to the left is a crowd scene in which everyone is drinking, and in the right background is an imagine of a bottle on graph paper)

Illustration by Art Spiegelman (misspelled on the cover as "Art Spielgelman," but spelled correctly on masthead; a café scene in which all characters are skeletons, including a "female" skeleton with large breasts and erect nipples, skeleton musicians, a skeleton dressed in stereotypical French artist garb with an erection standing on a table reading from a book and holding a bottle)
"Crisper" Impression - printed words distinguish themselves most clearly
"Less Clear" Impression - printed words bleed into the paper
Illustration by Elizabeth Brady (New York stoop-scene, in which one of the trash cans is on fire)
